DOC.HEAD: One Dead in Azerbaijan As Police Fire On Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Police fired on thousands of protesters seeking the ouster of a Communist Party chief in a town in the Azerbaijani republic, killing one person and wounding 162, an activist said Sunday. The crowd of 20,000 to 30,000 people in Dzhali-Abad, near the Iranian border and the Caspian Sea, surrounded the party headquarters Friday to demand the removal of Kherula Aliev, the regional party first secretary, Fazil Gamidov of the Azerbaijani People's Front said in a telephone interview. Aliev was appointed by Azerbaijan party chief Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, and the protesters wanted to elect their own leader, Gamidov said. Much of the region has been on strike for the previous 22 days over the issue, he added. Police shot and killed a 19-year-old man when officers tried to clear the area, Gamidov said. Some of the injured also had been shot, and all the wounded were civilians, he said. Party officials fled and police sealed off the party headquarters, Gamidov said. He did not know how the incident turned violent. But he said no troops were involved, only local police. On Saturday, witnesses told a rally in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku about the confrontation.
